question: What period of time must a person be hospitalized before an injury may be defined by the NTSB as a 'serious injury'?
choices: 72 hours; commencing within 10 days after date of the injury.
48 hours; commencing within 7 days after date of the injury.
10 days, with no other extenuating circumstances.

question: Which is true with respect to a high - or low-pressure system?
choices: A low-pressure area or trough is an area of descending air.
A high-pressure area or ridge is an area of rising air.
A high-pressure area or ridge is an area of descending air.

question: How should the flight controls be held while taxiing a tricycle-gear equipped airplane into a left quartering headwind?
choices: Left aileron up, elevator neutral.
Left aileron down, elevator neutral.
Left aileron up, elevator down.

question: After landing at a tower-controlled airport, when should the pilot contact ground control?
choices: Prior to turning off the runway.
After reaching a taxiway that leads directly to the parking area.
When advised by the tower to do so.

question: What is an important airspeed limitation that is not color coded on airspeed indicators?
choices: Never-exceed speed.
Maximum structural cruising speed.
Maneuvering speed.

question: Cold air generally contains:
choices: More water vapor than cold air.
More suspended water particles.
Less water vapor than warm air.

question: One in-flight condition necessary for structural icing to form is
choices: stratiform clouds.
small temperature/dewpoint spread.
visible moisture.

question: Steady precipitation preceding a front is an indication of
choices: stratiform clouds with moderate turbulence.
cumuliform clouds with little or no turbulence.
stratiform clouds with little or no turbulence.

question: Under what condition will true altitude be lower than indicated altitude?
choices: When density altitude is higher than indicated altitude.
In colder than standard air temperature.
In warmer than standard air temperature.

question: When the course deviation indicator (CDI) needle is centered during an omnireceiver check using a VOR test signal (VOT), the omnibearing selector (OBS) and the TO/FROM indicator should read
choices: 0° TO or 180° FROM, regardless of the pilot's position from the VOT.
180° FROM, only if the pilot is due north of the VOT.
0° FROM or 180° TO, regardless of the pilot's position from the VOT.

question: One of the most easily recognized discontinuities across a front is
choices: a change in temperature.
an increase in relative humidity.
an increase in cloud coverage.

question: What does a steady red light signal from an ATC control tower mean when in flight?
choices: Exercise extreme caution
Airport unsafe, do not land
Give way and continue circling

question: How many GPS satellites are required to provide a three-dimensional position?
What is the minimum number of Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites that are observable by a user anywhere on earth?
(Refer to Figure 68.) On the wind triangle, the line from point C to B represents:
choices: True heading and groundspeed.
Airspeed and heading.
Groundspeed and true course.

question: (Refer to Figure 68.) On the wind triangle, the line from point C to A represents:
choices: Wind direction and velocity.
True heading and groundspeed.
True course and groundspeed.

question: (Refer to Figure 68.) B of the wind triangle represent?
choices: Groundspeed and true heading.
True course and groundspeed.
True heading and airspeed.

question: The movement of the air affects the speed at which aircraft move:
choices: In a turn.
Over the Earth's surface.
Through the air.

question: Inbound to an airport with no tower, FSS, or UNICOM in operation, a pilot should self-announce on MULTICOM frequency
If a person is convicted of flying an airplane while intoxicated, he or she might expect:
choices: Denial of an application for an FAA certificate or rating.
To write a report to the FAA Civil Aviation Security Division (AMC-700) not later than 60 day after the conviction.
To write a notification of the conviction to the FAA Civil Aeromedical Institute.

question: How is the wing twisted on most training airplanes to increase controllability at low speeds?
choices: The wing is twisted to a higher AOA at the wing tip.
The wing is twisted to a lower AOA at the wing root.
The wing is twisted to a higher AOA at the wing root.

question: What is/are the aircraft inspection requirement(s) when receiving dual flight instruction in your own airplane?
choices: 100-hour inspection
Annual inspection
Annual inspection and a 100-hour inspection

question: Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is the continuous broadcast of recorded information concerning
choices: pilots of radar-identified aircraft whose aircraft is in dangerous proximity to terrain or to an obstruction.
noncontrol information in selected high-activity terminal areas.
nonessential information to reduce frequency congestion.

question: When are non-rechargeable batteries of an emergency locator transmitter (ELT) required to be replaced?
choices: At the time of each 100-hour or annual inspection.
Every 24 months.
When 50 percent of their useful life expires.

question: While operating under BasicMed, the pilot in command must have visited their primary care physician within the preceding:
choices: 48 months.
12 months.
24 months.

question: The most accurate part of a forecast occurs:
choices: At the end of the forecast period.
Some hours after the forecast period.
At the beginning of the forecast period.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, if an aircraft is accelerated or decelerated, the magnetic compass will normally indicate
choices: correctly when on a north or south heading.
a turn toward the south.
a turn momentarily.

question: What should be the indication on the magnetic compass as you roll into a standard rate turn to the right from a south heading in the Northern Hemisphere?
choices: The compass will remain on south for a short time, then gradually catch up to the magnetic heading of the airplane.
The compass will indicate a turn to the right, but at a faster rate than is actually occurring.
The compass will initially indicate a turn to the left.

question: (Refer to Figure 9, area B.) How should the flight controls be held while taxiing a tailwheel airplane into a right quartering headwind?
choices: Right aileron up, elevator up.
Right aileron down, elevator neutral.
Right aileron up, elevator down.

question: Which conditions result in the formation of frost?
choices: The temperature of the surrounding air is at or below freezing when small drops of moisture fall on the collecting surface.
The temperature of the collecting surface is at or below the dewpoint of the adjacent air and the dewpoint is below freezing.
The temperature of the collecting surface is at or below freezing when small droplets of moisture fall on the surface.

question: The purpose of the fuel tank vent system is to:
choices: allow air to enter as fuel is consumed to maintain atmospheric pressure inside the tank.
allow for the proper air to fuel ratio when flying at higher altitudes.
increase pressure in the tank to move fuel to the engine intake.

question: When does P-factor cause the airplane to yaw to the left?
choices: When at high airspeeds.
When at high angles of attack.
When at low angles of attack.

question: What is the purpose of the taxiway directional sign?
choices: Indicates designation and direction of exit taxiway from runway.
Indicates direction to take-off runway.
Indicates designation and direction of taxiway leading out of an intersection.

question: The vertical limit of Class C airspace above the primary airport is normally
choices: 4,000 feet AGL.
3,000 feet AGL.
1,200 feet AGL.

question: Parasite drag increases when airspeed is:
choices: Parasite drag always remains constant.
Increased.
Decreased.

question: Which statement is most correct regarding form drag?
choices: Form drag increases as airspeed increases.
It decreases as the speed of the airplane increases.
It increases when the weight of the airplane increases.

question: At the beginning of a turn from a northerly heading:
choices: The compass will lead the turn.
The compass will show a turn in the opposite direction.
The compass will show the correct heading.

question: Inland fog is most likely:
choices: Advection fog sometimes called sea fog.
Precipitation Induced fog.
Radiation Fog sometimes called ground fog.

question: To maintain BasicMed privileges, you must complete a BasicMed medical education course within the preceding:
choices: 24 calendar months.
48 calendar months.
12 calendar months.

question: What feature is associated with a temperature inversion?
choices: An unstable layer of air.
Chinook winds on mountain slopes.
A stable layer of air.

question: A TAF includes:
choices: Wind, visibility, weather phenomena, obstructions to vision, and cloud coverage.
Wind, visibility, cloud coverage, and cloud tops in feet MSL.
Wind, obstructions to vision, and cloud tops in feet MSL.

question: In order to find pictorial explanations of airport signs and markings, which publication would you consult?
choices: Aeronautical Information Manual (AIM).
Advisory Circulars (ACs) under subject number 90.
Chart Supplements.

question: When taxiing with strong quartering tailwinds, which aileron positions should be used?
choices: Aileron down on the downwind side.
Ailerons neutral.
Aileron down on the side from which the wind is blowing.

question: A special VFR clearance authorizes the pilot of an aircraft to operate VFR while within Class D airspace when the visibility is
choices: at least 3 miles and the aircraft can remain clear of clouds.
less than 1 mile and the ceiling is less than 1,000 feet.
at least 1 mile and the aircraft can remain clear of clouds.

question: Eye movements during daytime collision avoidance scanning should:
choices: be in 30 degree sectors and view each sector for at least 3 seconds.
use peripheral vision by scanning small sectors and utilizing off-center viewing.
not exceed 10 degrees and view each sector at least 1 second.

question: Induced drag increases when airspeed is:
choices: Increased.
Decreased.
Increased by a factor of two.

question: Unless otherwise authorized, the maximum indicated airspeed at which aircraft may be flown when at or below 2,500 feet AGL and within 4 nautical miles of the primary airport of Class C airspace is
choices: 250 knots.
200 knots.
230 knots.

question: For a given power setting with a constant-speed, variable pitch propeller:
choices: Low pitch results in high RPM.
Low pitch results in low RPM.
High pitch results in high RPM.

question: As you are climbing to your cruise altitude, you realize you forgot to lean the mixture control. What happens to fuel/air mixture entering the engine?
choices: The fuel-air mixture becomes richer because the density of air decreases while the amount of fuel remains constant.
The fuel-air mixture is leaner because the density of air increases while the amount of fuel remains constant.
Altitude has no effect on the fuel/air mixture in modern airplane engines.

question: The lateral dimensions of Class D airspace are based on
choices: the instrument procedures for which the controlled airspace is established.
the number of airports that lie within the Class D airspace.
5 statute miles from the geographical center of the primary airport.

question: While cruising at 9,500 feet MSL, the fuel/air mixture is properly adjusted. What will occur if a descent to 4,500 feet MSL is made without readjusting the mixture?
choices: The fuel/air mixture may become excessively lean.
There will be more fuel in the cylinders than is needed for normal combustion, and the excess fuel will absorb heat and cool the engine.
The excessively rich mixture will create higher cylinder head temperatures and may cause detonation.

question: What are the reporting requirements for a pilot convicted of possessing and selling marijuana?
choices: You must send a notification letter with details of the conviction within 60 days to the Aerospace Medical Certification Division.
There are no reporting requirements related to marijuana offenses.
You must report the offense to the FAA Aeromedical Certification Division when applying for a medical certificate.

question: The purpose of the fuel tank vent system is to:
choices: allow air to enter as fuel is consumed to maintain atmospheric pressure inside the tank.
allow for the proper air to fuel ratio when flying at higher altitudes.
increase pressure in the tank to move fuel to the engine intake.

question: The conditions necessary for the formation of cumulonimbus clouds are a lifting action and:
choices: unstable, moist air.
either stable or unstable air.
unstable air containing an excess of condensation nuclei.

question: The wind at 5,000 feet AGL is southwesterly while the surface wind is southerly. This difference in direction is primarily due to
choices: friction between the wind and the surface.
stronger Coriolis force at the surface.
stronger pressure gradient at higher altitudes.

question: You can expect dangerous turbulence in mountain waves and:
choices: Below rotor clouds.
Above rotor clouds.
Below lenticular clouds.

question: What cloud types would indicate convective turbulence?
choices: Cirrus clouds.
Towering cumulus clouds.
Nimbostratus clouds.

question: Low level inversions may cause:
choices: Clearing of the atmosphere close to the surface.
Precipitation.
Smoke and dust to be trapped close to the surface.

question: Lateral or roll stability is normally achieved by:
choices: The design of the horizontal stabilizer/stabilator.
The upward pitch of the wings, called dihedral.
The design of the ailerons.

question: What effect does high density altitude, as compared to low density altitude, have on propeller efficiency and why?
choices: Efficiency is increased due to less friction on the propeller blades.
Efficiency is reduced due to the increased force of the propeller in the thinner air.
Efficiency is reduced because the propeller exerts less force at high density altitudes than at low density altitudes.

question: Layered clouds are called:
choices: Cumulus.
Mares' tails.
Stratus.

question: What action can a pilot take to aid in cooling an engine that is overheating during a climb?
choices: Reduce rate of climb and increase airspeed.
Reduce climb speed and increase RPM.
Increase climb speed and increase RPM.

question: To obtain current information regarding cloud tops, icing, and turbulence check the:
choices: Graphical Forecasts for Aviation (GFA).
Pilot reports (PIREPs).
Low-Level Significant Weather Prog Charts.

question: In what flight condition is torque effect the greatest in a single-engine airplane?
choices: Low airspeed, high power, high angle of attack.
High airspeed, high power, high angle of attack.
Low airspeed, low power, low angle of attack.

question: Every physical process of weather is accompanied by, or is the result of, a:
choices: heat exchange.
pressure differential.
movement of air.

question: After takeoff you encounter a temperature inversion. You should expect:
choices: Wind shear.
Strong convective currents.
Strong surface winds.

question: Which combination of atmospheric conditions will reduce aircraft takeoff and climb performance?
choices: High temperature, high relative humidity, and high density altitude.
High temperature, low relative humidity, and low density altitude.
Low temperature, low relative humidity, and low density altitude.

question: How often must the aircraft’s ELT be inspected?
choices: Within 12 calendar months of the last inspection
Every two years
Within 24 calendar months of the last inspection

question: What would be a symptom of hyperventilation?
choices: Decreased breathing rate and depth.
A feeling of suffocation and drowsiness.
Heightened awareness and feeling of well being.

question: Inbound to an airport with no tower, FSS, or UNICOM in operation, a pilot should self-announce on MULTICOM frequency
choices: 5 miles out.
20 miles out.
10 miles out.

question: A Third-Class Medical Certificate is issued to a 51-year-old pilot on May 3, this year. To exercise the privileges of a Private Pilot Certificate, the medical certificate will be valid until midnight on
choices: May 3, 1 year later.
May 31, 1 year later.
May 31, 2 years later.

question: In which situation is advection fog most likely to form?
choices: An air mass moving inland from the coast in winter.
A warm, moist air mass on the windward side of mountains.
A light breeze blowing colder air out to sea.

question: If a pilot suspects that the engine (with a fixed-pitch propeller) is detonating during climb-out after takeoff, the initial corrective action to take would be to
choices: apply carburetor heat
lean the mixture
lower the nose slightly to increase airspeed

question: What is indicated when a current CONVECTIVE SIGMET forecasts thunderstorms?
choices: Moderate thunderstorms covering 30 percent of the area.
Moderate or severe turbulence.
Thunderstorms obscured by massive cloud layers.

question: Induced drag increases with:
choices: An increase in the angle of attack.
A decrease in the angle of attack.
The speed of the airplane.

question: (Refer to Figure 21, area 3.) What type military flight operations should a pilot expect along IR 644?
choices: IFR training flights above 1,500 feet AGL at speeds in excess of 250 knots.
VFR training flights above 1,500 feet AGL at speeds less than 250 knots.
Instrument training flights below 1,500 feet AGL at speeds in excess of 150 knots.

question: What is one of the advantages of an alternator over a generator in an airplane engine?
choices: The electrical output of an alternator is more constant throughout a wide range of engine speeds.
Alternators produce direct current rather than alternating current.
An alternator is electrically driven.

question: Unless each occupant is provided with supplemental oxygen, no person may operate a civil aircraft of U.S. registry above a maximum cabin pressure altitude of:
choices: 14,000 feet MSL.
15,000 feet MSL.
12,500 feet MSL.

question: The most frequent type of ground or surface-based temperature inversion is that which is produced by
choices: terrestrial radiation on a clear, relatively still night.
warm air being lifted rapidly aloft in the vicinity of mountainous terrain.
the movement of colder air under warm air, or the movement of warm air over cold air.

question: The uncontrolled firing of the fuel/air charge in advance of normal spark ignition is known as
choices: combustion.
pre-ignition.
detonation.

question: The presence of ice pellets at the surface is evidence that there
choices: are thunderstorms in the area.
has been a cold frontal passage.
is a temperature inversion with freezing rain at a higher altitude.

question: Select the true statement about BasicMed medical certificate requirements:
choices: A pilot whose medical certificate expired in 2002 does not need to get a current medical to qualify for BasicMed.
If a pilot has never had a medical certificate, he or she must get one before they qualify to operate under BasicMed.
A pilot whose medical certificate has been revoked can operate under BasicMed instead of getting his or her medical reinstated.

question: When warm, moist, stable air flows upslope, it
choices: produced stratus type clouds.
causes showers and thunderstorms.
develops convective turbulence.

question: To determine the freezing level and areas of probable icing aloft, the pilot should refer to the
choices: Weather Depiction Chart.
Area Forecast.
Inflight Aviation Weather Advisories.

question: (Refer to Figure 19.) How are Significant Weather Prognostic Charts best used by a pilot?
choices: For determining areas to avoid (freezing levels and turbulence).
For overall planning at all altitudes.
For analyzing current frontal activity and cloud coverage.

question: How soon after the conviction for driving while intoxicated by alcohol or drugs shall it be reported to the FAA, Civil Aviation Security Division?
choices: Required to be reported upon renewal of medical certificate.
No later than 30 working days after the motor vehicle action.
No later than 60 days after the motor vehicle action.

question: Maintenance records show the last transponder inspection was performed on September 1, 2014. The next inspection will be due no later than
choices: September 30, 2015.
September 1, 2016.
September 30, 2016.

question: Under the general BasicMed rules a pilot can fly
choices: carrying passengers or cargo for compensation or hire.
without restrictions outside of the United States.
in furtherance of a business.

question: For aviation purposes, ceiling is defined as the height above the Earth's surface of the
choices: lowest reported obscuration and the highest layer of clouds reported as overcast.
lowest broken or overcast layer or vertical visibility into an obscuration.
lowest layer of clouds reported as scattered, broken, or thin.

question: The Air Data Computer or ADC
choices: gathers pressure information from spinning gyros.
combines data from the pitot-static sensors and temperature sensors.
receives input from the airspeed and altitude indicators.

question: If a flight is made from an area of low pressure into an area of high pressure without the altimeter setting being adjusted, the altimeter will indicate
choices: the actual altitude above sea level.
higher than the actual altitude above sea level.
lower than the actual altitude above sea level.

question: A stable air mass is most likely to have which characteristic?
choices: Showery precipitation.
Turbulent air.
Smooth air.

question: If the temperature/dewpoint spread is small and decreasing, and the temperature is 62 °F, what type weather is most likely to develop?
choices: Freezing precipitation.
Thunderstorms.
Fog or low clouds.

question: Magnetic heading is
choices: the number you want to see in the glass of the compass to fly where you want to go.
the direction the nose is pointed referenced to magnetic north.
the error in the compass due to magnetic fields in the aircraft.

question: To use an MEL a pilot
choices: may download it from the manufacturer's website.
must receive written approval from the FAA.
may refer to it in the AFM, no further action is needed.

question: In what controlled airspace are you not required to contact ATC when flying in VMC?
choices: TRSA.
Class C.
Class D.

question: FAA advisory circulars (some free, others at cost) are available to all pilots and are obtained by
choices: distribution from the nearest FAA district office.
ordering those desired from the Government Printing Office.
subscribing to the Federal Register.
